lines.content: SleepyVoid is a chatbot with cat ASCII art made to help users manage and organize their tasks.
It allows you to add and track tasks, deadlines, and events, remove completed tasks.
It has multiple features such as deadline tracking, event scheduling, task completion marking, storage, and more.
### Note: All commands are not case sensitive
The main function of SleepyVoid is task management, and below are the 3 task types.
They each have different features, so you can choose one of them to use that best fits your task.
`todo` stores simple tasks that can be completed without any time specification.
It is ideal for tasks that do not have a specific deadline or schedule.
To add a `todo` task, use the following command:
After successfully adding a todo task,
you will see the expected output below
Now there's 2 pending task(s) in the list.
- The format of your task would be `[T][ ] task description`.
- The first `[T]` indicates that it is a `todo` task.
- The second `[ ]` shows the completion status, which will be elaborated below
* **No time requirement:**  `Todo` can be used for any general tasks
`deadline` stores tasks with a specific due date and time, which is good to use for tasks that have to be completed before a certain deadline.
To add a `deadline` task, use the following command:
Date and time can be keyed in any format as you wish to.
The output of successfully adding a `deadline` task is similar to adding a `todo` task.
Now there's 2 pending task(s) in the list.
- The format would be `[D][ ] task description (by: date and time)`.
- `[D]` represent that this task is a `deadline` task.
* **Time Required:** `deadline` must contain a command `/by` and an input after, to ensure no errors
`event` is a `task` type that stores tasks or activities that have a start and end time.
This makes it suitable for events in a time block, such as meetings or appointments.
To add a `event` task, use the following command:
event [task description] /from [start date and time] /to [end date and time]
**Notice:**  the format of date and time is the same as `deadline`.
The output of successfully adding a `event` task is similar to the previous 2 `task` types
Now there's 3 pending task(s) in the list.
- The format of your task would be `[E][ ] task description (from: start date and time to: end date and time)`.
- `[E]` represent that this task is an `event` task
- The bracket `(from: _ to: _)`shows the event duration
* **Time Duration Required:** `event` must contain a start time and end time.
To help manage the tasks, we provide a set of useful commands that you can use to interact with SleepyVoid.
**Notice:** The command is not type sensitive
Below are the available commands and their functionalities:
`list` is a command that list all the tasks currently stored in SleepyVoid.
To list all the tasks, you can use the following command:
`remove` allows you to delete a task from the list.
To remove a task, you can use following command:
- `index` is the index of the task in the list, which can be viewed from listing the list via the  `list ` command
- The number in front of the task is the task index to use.
Once the chatbot delete the task from the list, you will find the expected output below:
When you type `list` again, the list will now look like this
Mark allows you to mark your task as completed, thus allowing you to check it off the list
To mark a task, you can use the following command:
* Same as `delete` command, the index is the number of the task in the list.
Type in these two command in sequence:
The expected output of command `mark 1` would be:
/ᐠ˵, ,˵マ Nice! I've marked this task as done:
`find` is used for finding the specific tasks using a keyword.
You can find specific tasks that contains the keyword in the task description.
To find a specific task, you can use following command:
* `description` is the keyword that your target tasks should contain.
If a task contains the keyword, it will be displayed to you
Suppose we want to find tasks that contains the keyword assignment, we can use `find` command:
The expected output is shown below:
/ᐠ˵o o˵マ Here are the matching tasks in your list:
To end the conversation with SleepyVoid, you can use the following command:
The chatbot will end the conversation, and you can use it again if you wish to add more tasks.
All the data is auto saved, thus when you restart the chat, all the previously listed tasks will still be inside.
Any updates made to the list will be autosaved as well.
The saved data will be automatically loaded to the chat when the conversation starts, and can be checked by using the `list` command.
You can access to the saved data via the following path:\
The format of data would be:
**Notice:** It is discouraged for you to modify data directly inside the file `SleepyVoid.txt`.
If you have to change data in `list.txt`, please follow the same format.
If not, it will cause error when loading your data to SleepyVoid.
If you encounter any errors when loading the file, please delete all the data in the file `SleepyVoid.txt`, and added them again via the chatbot
- If any required details are missing or incorrectly formatted,
the system will prompt an error, and show the steps you can take to use the correct command
* The SleepyVoid class is a chatbot named SleepyVoid that manages all tasks.
* Represents a chatbot SleepyVoid that manages task list, storage, ui and parser objects
* to manage tasks inputted by the user.
* Creates a new instance of {@code SleepyVoid}.
* Initializes the user interface, storage, parser, and loads tasks from the text file.
* Displays a welcome message, shows available commands, then continuously processes user commands.
* Chatbot ends and exits when the user inputs "bye".
* The entry point of the program.
* @param args Command-line arguments not used in this application.
Strings.LEADING_SPACE + "To add a deadline to the list, type: deadline XX /by XX (Don't miss out the /!..)");
+ "To add an event to the list, type: event XX /from XX /to XX (Don't miss out the /!..)");
ui.printMessage("Invalid input format, please add the keyword you want to find after the command \n" +
Strings.LEADING_SPACE + "eg To find tasks with the related keyword in the list, type: find [keyword]");
ui.printMessage("Invalid input format, please add the task number after the command \n" +
Strings.LEADING_SPACE + "eg To remove a task in the list, type: remove [task index]");
ui.printMessage("Missing input after the todo command, please key in the task after the todo command (eg todo XX)");
* The Deadlines class represents a deadline task.
* It extends from the abstract Task class and provides specific functionality for deadline tasks,
* such as storing the deadline and customizing the string representation and file format for saving.
* Creates a new Deadlines instance with the specified description and deadline.
* @param description The description of the deadline task based on the user input.
* @param deadline    The deadline of the task.
* Returns the task type identifier for a deadline task.
* @return A string representing the task type ("D" for deadline).
* Returns a string representation of the deadline task, including its type, status, description,
* @return A string representation of the deadline task.
* Returns a formatted string representation of the deadline task for saving to a file.
* The format includes the task type, default file format from the superclass, and the deadline.
* @return A string representation of the deadline task in file format.
* The Events class represents an event task.
* It extends the abstract Task class and provides specific functionality for event tasks,
* such as storing the start and end times of the event and customizing the string representation
* Constructs a new Events instance with the specified task description, start time, and end time.
* @param description The description of the event task.
* @param from        The start time or date of the event.
* @param to          The end time or date of the event.
public Events(String description, String from, String to) {
* Returns the task type identifier for an event task.
* @return A string representing the task type ("E" for event).
* Returns a string representation of the event task, including its type, status, description,
* @return A string representation of the event task.
* Returns a formatted string representation of the event task for saving to a text file.
* The format includes the task type, default file format from Task class, and the start and end times.
* @return A string representation of the event task in file format.
* An abstract class that represents a task.
* Provides common functionality and attributes for all types of tasks,
* such as a description, completion status, and methods to mark tasks as done.
* Creates a Task with a description based on user input and initialise its completion status to false (not done).
* @param description The task given by the user.
* Returns the status icon for the task.
* Returns "X" if the task is marked as done, and " " if not done.
* @return String representing the status icon of the task.
* Returns the type of the task.
* This method is intended to be overridden by subclasses to provide the specific task types.
* @return A string representing the task type
* Returns a string representation of the task,
* together with additional information such as its type and completion status.
* @return A string representation of the task and its related information
* Marks the task as done by setting the completion status to true.
* Returns a formatted string representation of the task and its related information for saving to a text file.
* @return A string representation of the task in file format to be added in a text file.
* The Todos class represents a todo task.
* It extends the abstract Task class and provides specific functionality for todo tasks,
* such as a task type identifier and a custom file format for saving.
* Creates a new Todos instance with the given user input.
* @param description The description of the todo task provided by the user.
* Returns the task type identifier for a todo task.
* @return A string representing the task type ("T" for todo).
* Returns a formatted string representation of the todo task for saving to a text file.
* The format adds the task type and the default file format provided by Task class.
* @return A string representation of the todo task in text file format.
* The Parser class processes user commands and executes the corresponding actions.
* It interacts with the TaskList, Storage, and Ui classes to manage tasks, save them and provide feedback to the user.
* Constructs a new Parser instance with the specified TaskList, Storage, and Ui.
* @param taskList The TaskList containing the tasks to be managed.
* @param storage  The Storage object used to save tasks to a file.
* @param ui       The Ui object used to interact with the user.
public Parser(TaskList taskList, Storage storage, Ui ui) {

* The Storage class handles file operations.
* It ensures that tasks are loaded and saved to a text file.
* Constructs a new Storage instance, ensuring the storage file exists and reading tasks from it.
* Creates the data directory if it does not already exist.
* Loads tasks from the specified text file.
* If the file does not exist, an empty list is returned.
* The file is expected to contain tasks in a specific format, and each task is parsed accordingly.
* @return An {@link ArrayList} of {@link Task} objects loaded from the file.
